title: National Football League
text: package created explore world National Football League (NFL). NFL premier professional American football league United States, consisting 32 teams divided two conferences four division . known physical gameplay, complex rules, culminates Super Bowl, one world’s -watched sporting events. package offers users access fundamental NFL facts engaging datasets game attendance results. also includes convenient functions launch interactive Shiny App NFL statistics plot winning trend graphs individual NFL teams ease. also additional function help calculate mean level categorical variable.

title: National Football League
text: document introduces nflexplore’s usage. instance, two sample datasets can called, : attendance : Dataset shows total attendance NFL game per week per team, spanning multiple years 2000 2019. games : Dataset contains information weekly games, providing details winning team game performances. utilising two datasets, able perform simple data analysis add new knowledge NFL general. Let’s create example:

previous_headings: Introduction to nflexplore > Datasets and Use Case
what: 1. Plotting a yearly attendance (using attendance dataset)
title: National Football League
code: # Create a plot by summarising attendance number into yearly basis attendance %>%     filter(week == 1) %>%     group_by(year) %>%     summarise(total = sum(total),               home = sum(home)) %>%     ggplot(aes(x = year, y = total, group = 1)) +       geom_line(size = 1) +       geom_point(size = 3) +       theme_classic() +       scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma)

previous_headings: Introduction to nflexplore > Datasets and Use Case
what: 2. Top 5 team with most win (using games dataset)
title: National Football League
code: #Creating home/away win table home_away <- games %>%                  group_by(year, home_team) %>%                  summarise(home = sum(home_win),                            away = sum(away_win)) %>%                  pivot_longer(c("home","away"),                               names_to = "home_aways",                               values_to = "win_number")  #Summarising home/away win table home_away_summ <- home_away %>%                     group_by(home_team) %>%                     summarise(total_win = sum(win_number))                      #Plotting for Home & Away Win home_away_summ %>%     slice_max(total_win, n = 5) %>%     ggplot(aes(x = reorder(home_team, total_win), y = total_win)) +       geom_bar(position = "dodge", stat = "identity") +       coord_flip() +       xlab("Team") +       ylab("Number of Win") +       theme_classic()

title: National Football League
text: Apart dataset, package also include functions. three functions serves increase knowledge NFL, run_app: function open Shiny App created author, provides preliminary knowledge NFL. win_trend: function return home/away winning trend certain NFL team. calculate_means: function calculate mean level categorical variable returns named numeric vector means. Let’s explore ability function:

previous_headings: Introduction to nflexplore > Functions and Use Case
title: National Football League
text: Whenever call function, open Shiny App provides preliminary knowledge NFL. interactive web application, can play around plot. example, can change filter provided application, plot change accordingly. addition , short video explaining NFL games played, including game structure, teams score points, rules game.

previous_headings: Introduction to nflexplore > Functions and Use Case
title: National Football League
text: run function, need prepare one NFL team want see winning trend. can refer NFL official website complete list team . identified team want explore, can input function. example:

previous_headings: Introduction to nflexplore > Functions and Use Case
title: National Football League
text: function takes numeric vector categorical vector input. calculates mean level categorical variable returns named numeric vector means. example use :
code: numeric_data <- c(10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35) category_data <- c("A", "B", "A", "B", "A", "B")  calculate_means(numeric_data, category_data) #> [1] 20 25

title: Authors and Citation
text: Evan Ginting. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ginting E (2023). nflexplore: National Football League Exploratory Data Analysis. R package version 0.0.0.9000.
code: @Manual{,   title = {nflexplore: National Football League Exploratory Data Analysis},   author = {Evan Ginting},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000}, }

what: National Football League Exploratory Data Analysis
title: National Football League Exploratory Data Analysis
text: R package offers essential insights National Football League (NFL), providing access game attendance result datasets. Users can explore NFL statistics, visualize team winning trends, launch interactive Shiny App -depth analysis, making valuable tool NFL enthusiasts data enthusiasts alike. also additional function help calculate mean level categorical variable. summary, included R package: Datasets attendance contains total attendance NFL games per week per team. games information weekly games, providing details winning team game performances. Functions run_app Launch NFL Shiny App. win_trend Winning Trend NFL team. calculate_means Calculate means level categorical variable numeric vector.

title: National Football League Exploratory Data Analysis
text: can install development version nflexplore GitHub :
code: # install the development version from GitHub devtools::install_github("ETC5523-2023/rpkg-evanginting")

title: National Football League Exploratory Data Analysis
text: example can utilise R Package:
code: library(nflexplore) library(dplyr)  # Populating annual total attendance  attendance %>%     filter(week == 1) %>%     group_by(year) %>%     summarise(total = sum(total))         # Populating home/away win     games %>%     group_by(year, home_team) %>%     summarise(home = sum(home_win),               away = sum(away_win)) %>%     pivot_longer(c("home","away"),                  names_to = "home_aways",                  values_to = "win_number")                                     # Launching NFL Shiny App run_app()   # Getting winning trend of an NFL team win_trend("Dallas Cowboys")

title: Attendance Dataset — attendance
text: dataset contains total attendance NFL games per week per team. spans across multiple years 2000 2019.

title: Attendance Dataset — attendance
text: Data frame columns team Team City team_name Team name year Season year total Total attendance across 17 weeks (1 week = game) home Home attendance away Away attendance week Week number (1-17) weekly_attendance Weekly attendance number full_name Combination team variable team_name variable

title: Attendance Dataset — attendance
text: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2020/2020-02-04

what: Calculate means for each level of a categorical variable in a numeric vector — calculate_means
title: Calculate means for each level of a categorical variable in a numeric vector — calculate_means
text: function takes numeric vector categorical vector input. calculates mean level categorical variable returns named numeric vector means.

title: Calculate means for each level of a categorical variable in a numeric vector — calculate_means
Calculate means for each level of a categorical variable in a numeric vector — calculate_means
text: numeric_vector numeric vector containing data means calculated. categorical_vector character vector containing categorical variable.

title: Calculate means for each level of a categorical variable in a numeric vector — calculate_means
text: named numeric vector means level categorical variable.

title: Calculate means for each level of a categorical variable in a numeric vector — calculate_means
code: # Example Data numeric_data <- c(10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35) category_data <- c("A", "B", "A", "B", "A", "B")   # Calculate means for each category calculate_means(numeric_data, category_data) #> [1] 20 25

title: Games Dataset — games
text: dataset information weekly games, providing details winning team game performances. covers data 2000 2019.

title: Games Dataset — games
text: Data frame columns year season year, note playoff games still previous season week week number (1-17, plus playoffs) home_team Home team away_team Away team winner Winning team tie tie, "losing" team well day Day week date Date minus year time Time game start pts_win Points winning team pts_loss Points losing team yds_win Yards winning team turnovers_win Turnovers winning team yds_loss Yards losing team turnovers_loss Turnovers losing team home_team_name Home team name home_team_city Home team city away_team_name Away team name away_team_city Away team city home_win Identifier home win away_win Identifier away win

title: Games Dataset — games
text: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2020/2020-02-04

text: result calling rhs(lhs).

text: function launch shiny app shows preliminary facts NFL. interactive web application, can play around plot. example, can change filter provided application, plot change accordingly.

what: Winning Trend of an NFL team — win_trend
title: Winning Trend of an NFL team — win_trend
text: function takes name NFL team plots winning trend team. trend span across 2000 2019, separate lines indicating wins home away.

title: Winning Trend of an NFL team — win_trend
Winning Trend of an NFL team — win_trend
text: See full team list .

title: Winning Trend of an NFL team — win_trend
text: team NFL team name

title: Winning Trend of an NFL team — win_trend
text: trendline home away win years inputted NFL Team.

title: Winning Trend of an NFL team — win_trend
code: # Example Input "Arizona Cardinals" #> [1] "Arizona Cardinals"  # Plot the winning trend win_trend("Arizona Cardinals")
